results.title: What is life?
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Joseph Koenig and Robert Verrall
results.brief_description: What is it that distinguishes the living organism from the non-living, the particular quality common to all living forms? This animated film provides lucid explanation, arresting in colour and form as the facts are presented. It shows what biophysics and biochemistry now perceive as the facts of life concerning evolution and the genetically determining factor of the DNA molecule.

results.title: What is inflation?
results.brief_description: Defines the concept of inflation and the motions open to government in dealing with it. Reconstructs the political, social, and natural factors which have given rise to the new phenomenon of stagflation.

results.title: What is fitness exercise?
results.brief_description: Uses a combination of animation and live-action to illustrate the benefits of physical fitness. A good sorceress teaches a scrawny knight the value being fit on general health and knightly pursuits. As he travels the kingdom he learns the elements of physical fitness, the correct way to exercise, the need to develop personal fitness levels and how being fit relates to health, work, sport and regular routines.

results.title: What is electricty
results.creator_credit: Frank A. Hoare and Langton Gould-Marks
results.brief_description: Commencing with a quick survey of the outstanding discoveries which led to the discovery and use of electric current, this film then answers the question put in the title. Opens with a survey of those outstanding discoveries which led to the development and use of eclectic current. Diagrams are used to explain the concept of matter as composed of atoms, each consisting of a nucleus and revolving electrons, electric current is explained as being a movement of these electrons.

results.title: What is ecology? - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Bert Van Bork
results.brief_description: Defines and illustrates basic terms in the science of ecology. Explores plant and animal relationships and their interdependence for survival through several major biomes. Addresses the constant danger of human activity to the ecological balance.

results.title: What is disease?
results.brief_description: A simple explanation of the nature of disease. Shows how diseases are transmitted and the deadly result of lack of personal and domestic cleanliness. Made specifically for South American native audiences.

results.title: What is cancer?
results.brief_description: This film was prepared specifically for the nursing profession. Explains the biology of the disease and emphasises that nurses have a special role in early diagnosis of the disease and in the rehabilitation of patients. Illustrates the origin of caner in the body, the nature of cancer cells, and the spread of the disease through the body. Shows four methods of treatment; surgery, X-ray, radium, and the use of hormones. Charts are used to illustrate the importance of early cancer diagnosis. Explains how the nurse, understanding that cancer can be cured can help the patient overcome psychological fears and resume a normal life. Warning: some scenes may disturb.

results.title: What is an original print?
results.creator_credit: RATAS Arts Consultancy and Oxide City Productions
results.brief_description: A guide to the processes and techniques of original printmaking. Demonstrates relief prints (woodcuts, linocuts), incised or intaglio prints (engravings, etchings), lithography and serigraphy (silkscreen). Presented by Josef Lebovic.

results.title: What is a word processor? or Tale of two sisters
results.creator_credit: Video Arts, IBM (UK), Robert Reid and Peter Robinson
results.brief_description: A John Cleese training film which explains the principles and illustrates the nature of word processing. Shows all the aspects of office work which the processor can make quicker or easier, and provides a framework of understanding which dispels the mystery and threat surrounding this technology. Features John Cleese, Alison Steadman, Kay Stonham and Carol Hawkins. Photography by Arthur Wooster, sound by Bruce White, edited by Colin Sherman, narrated by Judi Dench, written by David Nobbs.
